intro: Mariscus chionocephalus, commonly known as the white-headed bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, white to pale blue flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has basal leaves that are lanceolate and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and branched. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
